learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyse, evaluate and position an argument on a body of literature or creative works according to disciplinary conventions.
Articulate a relevant research problem and contextualise your research question/s within its field.
Design a coherent methodology including appropriate research method/s that answer the stated research question/s.
Implement the research design through data collection or data-informed design practice.
Generate and synthesise findings through data analysis or reflective design practice.
Select and apply a range of communication strategies, including written, verbal and visual methods, according to disciplinary standards.
Reflect on appropriate, informed and ethical use of a range of research tools and methods, including AI where utilised.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 1 – Research Plan and Annotated Bibliography
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

This assessment establishes the intellectual foundation for the thesis. You will clearly articulate a relevant research problem and research question(s), and propose a coherent and feasible research plan. You will critically analyse and annotate relevant literature and/or creative works. Emphasis is placed on disciplinary-appropriate written and visual communication, as well as early ethical awareness, including reflective consideration of research tools and AI.

The assessment requires students to position their proposed thesis within an appropriate disciplinary context, to identify a relevant research problem, articulate the research intent, scope, and direction. Students may pursue either:

·      a research-based thesis, in which findings are generated through data collection and analysis, or

·      a research-led design thesis, in which evidence informs iterative design exploration and reflective practice.

 Both approaches must demonstrate scholarly rigour, critical judgement, and clarity of intent.

Complex / authentic assessment using AI and/or MT to support learning: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

After successfully submitting an assignment through Turnitin, a ‘Submission Complete!’ screen will be displayed. It is the student’s responsibility to check assignment preview and confirm successful submission. If the ‘Submission Complete!’ screen isn’t displayed, the student should regard the submission as unsuccessful. Students should download a copy of the digital receipt as proof they have submitted the assignment. Students who are experiencing upload issues must advise the Course Coordinator immediately by email and should include screenshots and a copy of the assessment for submission.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 2 – Literature Review, Methodology & Ethical Reflections
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

This assessment consolidates and formalises your thesis framework. You will achieve a depth and critical synthesis of literature and/or creative works, the clarity and relevance of the research problem and research question(s), and the coherence, rigour, and justification of the proposed methodology. Strong emphasis is placed on alignment between research intent, method, and anticipated outputs, as well as the quality and appropriateness of written and visual communication. Ethical awareness and reflective use of research tools, including AI, are integral at this stage.

The assessment marks the point at which the thesis moves from exploration to commitment. Students must demonstrate that their research problem is clearly articulated, well-positioned within the discipline, and supported by an appropriate and feasible research design.

Formative Feedback: You should be meeting and discussing drafts regularly with your advisor(s) during teaching weeks. Formative feedback is in Week 10 of Semester 1 2026, prior to which a draft chapter should be submitted directly to your advisor for feedback. Following the examination of the thesis, students will be required to make any recommended corrections or amendments to the satisfaction of the supervisor and course coordinator, and may choose to upload the corrected thesis to e-space.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment 3 –  Thesis Development and Final Document
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale:

This assessment requires students to demonstrate the application of their approved research methodology and to present emerging findings from their thesis project. Students are expected to show evidence of substantive research activity, including data collection, analysis, and/or data-informed design exploration. 

The assessment marks the transition from research design to research execution. Students must demonstrate that their methodological approach has been implemented as proposed, or appropriately adapted in response to findings, and that initial conclusions or insights have emerged.

Students may present findings generated through:

·      data-driven research and analysis, or

·      research-led design practice, in which evidence informs iterative design testing and reflective evaluation.

Both approaches must demonstrate rigour, coherence, and critical engagement with the research problem.
